lockPickTypes.title: Tension Wrench
lockPickTypes.text:
Primary use: Creating binding order and enabling all picking techniques

The most important tool in the kit. Controls how pins bind and set.

Technique:
- Use extremely light pressure for security pins.
- Reduce tension when spools or serrations counter-rotate.
- Increase slightly if pins feel loose.

Best for:
- All lock types
- Learning feedback and tactile control

lockPickTypes.title: Hook Pick
lockPickTypes.text:
Primary use: Single Pin Picking (SPP)

The hook pick is the most precise tool, perfect for individually lifting pins to their exact shear line. Ideal for high-quality locks or those with narrow keyways.

Technique:
- Apply very light tension.
- Test pins front to back to find the binding pin.
- Lift slowly until a clear click or reduction in tension occurs.
- Repeat until plug rotates.

Best for:
- Standard pin tumbler locks
- Spool, serrated, and mushroom pins
- Deep-set or isolated pins
- Paracentric keyways

lockPickTypes.title: Rake Pick
lockPickTypes.text:
Primary use: Rapid entry using chaotic motion

Rakes manipulate multiple pins at once and work exceptionally well on low–medium security locks.

Technique:
- Use moderate tension.
- Scrub, rock, or zip the pick in the keyway.
- Pause occasionally and add slight upward pressure.

Best for:
- Wide open keyways
- Standard pin stacks
- Quick entry
- Low-security household locks

lockPickTypes.title: Diamond Pick
lockPickTypes.text:
Primary use: Hybrid SPP + Raking tool

The diamond's angled face excels at sliding under pins or raking across multiple stacks.

Technique:
SPP:
- Use the tip like a shallow hook.
- Good for short pins or tight spaces.

Raking:
- Angle the pick and perform small back-and-forth movements.

Best for:
- Narrow/paracentric keyways
- Mixed high/low pinning
- Beginners learning hybrid techniques

lockPickTypes.title: Half-Diamond Pick
lockPickTypes.text:
Primary use: Versatile pick for wafers, pin tumblers, and directional raking

The half-diamond’s shape makes it excellent for lifting pins and gliding across surfaces.

Technique:
- Rocking motion on shallow pins
- SPP with tip like a miniature hook
- Raking by sweeping the angled face

Best for:
- Wafer locks
- Master locks
- Locks with shallow cuts

lockPickTypes.title: Snake Rake
lockPickTypes.text:
Primary use: Fast opening via rocking motion

The snake rake is shaped to match common pin patterns. It can open simple locks very quickly.

Technique:
- Insert fully, add moderate tension.
- Rock up and down while pulling outward.
- Repeat 2–3 cycles.

Best for:
- Cheap padlocks
- Filing cabinets
- Standard residential locks
- Beginner-friendly fast entry

lockPickTypes.title: City Rake
lockPickTypes.text:
Primary use: Simulating a key’s biting pattern

The city rake imitates a general key shape and works via controlled rocking.

Technique:
- Insert the rake.
- Apply light rocking and jiggle motions.
- Maintain consistent tension.

Best for:
- Locks with uniform pin heights
- Older locks
- Basic commercial locks

lockPickTypes.title: Deep Hook / Offset Hook
lockPickTypes.text:
Primary use: High/low pin stacks + isolating security pins

The deep hook reaches pins a standard hook can't access.

Technique:
- Very light tension required.
- Carefully lift deep-set or recessed pins.
- Ideal for isolating spools without oversetting neighbors.

Best for:
- Spool-heavy locks
- Deep cuts
- Paracentric keyways
- European cylinders

lockPickTypes.title: Ball Pick / Snowman pick
lockPickTypes.text:
Primary use: Wafer locks

Ball picks are designed to manipulate wafer locks found in cabinets, desks, and automotive systems.

Technique:
- Use gentle rotational tension.
- Rock the ball against wafers one at a time.
- Feel for subtle clicks.

Best for:
- Single-sided wafer locks
- Automotive locks
- Filing cabinets and office furniture
